:writing_hand::skin-tone-2: Machine Learning Workflows with Julia
I wanted to learn how to create machine learning models with Julia, so here’s my experience using Julia‘s MLJ package. A great API and a mature piece of software. <https://mdneuzerling.com/post/machine-learning-workflows-with-julia/>

elements.text: Cool post on mlj
https://twitter.com/mdneuzerling/status/1366479806615801856?s=19

text: MLJ is a pleasure to use. Thanks to <@UD0SQV5LL> and <@UAZP7LJLU> for helping me understand the finer details of MLJ’s evaluation strategies.

text: For sort of the formula syntax, can't you use `modelmatrix()` from StatsBase/Statistics (forgot which one)? Not ideal but similar to how before tidymodels in R, you would often have to use `model.matrix()`  to for example feed into glmnet(). Feel like there has gotta be a way to integrate formulas more directly into MLJ though too. I miss that as well.

elements.text: For sort of the formula syntax, can't you use
modelmatrix()
from StatsBase/Statistics (forgot which one)? Not ideal but similar to how before tidymodels in R, you would often have to use
model.matrix()
to for example feed into glmnet(). Feel like there has gotta be a way to integrate formulas more directly into MLJ though too. I miss that as well.

text: I think it's `StatsModels` you want, and yes people have been thinking about better integration of the `@formula` machinery but I believe no one is currently actively working on it

elements.text: I think it's
StatsModels
you want, and yes people have been thinking about better integration of the
@formula
machinery but I believe no one is currently actively working on it

text: I'm not sure what complexities are introduced with formulae and pre-processing, and if it's just filtering the input to the terms contained in the formula. The `recipes` R package handles formulae by giving every term a "role". The standard roles are "predictor" and "outcome" (from the formula), but they can be anything user-defined.  When you transform a term, the results inherit the role.

elements.text: I'm not sure what complexities are introduced with formulae and pre-processing, and if it's just filtering the input to the terms contained in the formula. The
recipes

R package handles formulae by giving every term a "role". The standard roles are "predictor" and "outcome" (from the formula), but they can be anything user-defined.  When you transform a term, the results inherit the role.

text: <@U0198R8T7LY> Thanks so much for taking the time to wrap you head around MLJ, and for making such a nice blog about its place in our growing julia ML ecosystem. Thanks also for the feedback. It’s feels good to have our work generously and publically acknowledged. :thankyou:

elements.text: Thanks so much for taking the time to wrap you head around MLJ, and for making such a nice blog about its place in our growing julia ML ecosystem. Thanks also for the feedback. It’s feels good to have our work generously and publically acknowledged.

text: And yeah, the formula thing keeps coming up. I think the most work on this has been done by <@U66M57AN4> at <https://github.com/kleinschmidt/Formulas.jl> . Be good to have integration into MLJ at some point.

text: It really is a minor, minor nitpick though

text: Yeah it would be great!  Don't have a ton of bandwidth to do it myself but like I said on twitter I'd be really happy to support/guide that effort :slightly_smiling_face:
